title: Ticket #4774: OOM Management issues
description:
RAL reported in htcondor-users they observed a signficant number of jobs going on hold with the following message in the ShadowLog: 

   10/08/14 14:26:26 (860002.0) (30272): ERROR "Error from slot1@xxxxxxxxxxxxxx: Close_Pipe error" at line ....

After a long debugging session with RAL, we noticed a few OOM notification management issues:

  1. When the VanillaProc object is destroyed, the m_oom_efd pipe is not de-registered (also, the other end of the pipe is never closed). The handler is active, so it's possible to get a use-after-free. The probability of this issue greatly increased in #4435 where it became possible to have the OOM-killer enabled along with the OOM notification (previously, the OOM-killer was always disabled when the OOM notification was enabled).
  2. VanillaProc is a sub-class allocated on the heap with no virtual destructor. Oops.
  3. Because the OOM killer can fire along with the OOM notification, we should check for the notification in VanillaProc::JobReaper. This way, it's much more likely we put the job on hold when the OOM killer is enabled and sent the job a SIGKILL.
  4. On newer kernels, when memory.use_hierarchy is enabled in the memory controller, attempting to disable the OOM killer fails with EINVAL in a not-top-level cgroup; this is the underlying cause of #4435. Now that we understand this is the problem, we ought to make the log message less scary.
remarks:
2014-Dec-16 13:15:08 by gthain:
CODE REVIEW

With this patch, in the reaper, we double check the OOM event fd to see if it has fired. Is there a race here, or are we guaranteed that it is hot by the time the starter's reaper is called?

Should we #ifdef LINUX the code in the reaper to do the event fd check? It should be -1 on all other platforms, but...

Otherwise, looks good to merge to V8_2-branch

2014-Dec-16 21:00:40 by bbockelm:
Hi Greg,

I don't particularly like to do unnecessary ifdef's; we already rely on the fact that (m_oom_efd == -1) outside "defined(HAVE_EVENTFD) && defined(HAVE_EXT_LIBCGROUP)".

Looking at the kernel code (well, the source tarball for 3.7.2 I happened to have on disk), the eventfd is always signaled before the OOM-killer routines run. I'm no expert, but I believe this guarantees there's no race condition.

That said, what happens if the race is possible in some future Linux 4.0? I would argue it's still OK; we already warn the user this race is possible in the starter log if disabling the OOM-killer failed.

Brian

2014-Dec-17 12:01:18 by gthain:
If we feel good about the event being delivered before the signal, let's merge it to 8.2
